sections.pali: [dī. ni. 3.332; cūḷani. posālamāṇavapucchāniddesa 83] ‘‘Sattimā, bhikkhave, viññāṇaṭṭhitiyo. Katamā satta? Santi, bhikkhave, sattā nānattakāyā nānattasaññino, seyyathāpi manussā, ekacce ca devā, ekacce ca vinipātikā. Ayaṃ paṭhamā viññāṇaṭṭhiti. ‘‘Santi, bhikkhave, sattā nānattakāyā ekattasaññino, seyyathāpi devā brahmakāyikā paṭhamābhinibbattā. Ayaṃ dutiyā viññāṇaṭṭhiti. ‘‘Santi, bhikkhave, sattā ekattakāyā nānattasaññino, seyyathāpi devā ābhassarā. Ayaṃ tatiyā viññāṇaṭṭhiti. ‘‘Santi, bhikkhave, sattā ekattakāyā ekattasaññino, seyyathāpi devā subhakiṇhā. Ayaṃ catutthā viññāṇaṭṭhiti. ‘‘Santi, bhikkhave, sattā sabbaso rūpasaññānaṃ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṃ atthaṅgamā nānattasaññānaṃ amanasikārā ‘ananto ākāso’ti ākāsānañcāyatanūpagā. Ayaṃ pañcamā viññāṇaṭṭhiti. ‘‘Santi, bhikkhave, sattā sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma ‘anantaṃ viññāṇa’nti viññāṇañcāyatanūpagā. Ayaṃ chaṭṭhā viññāṇaṭṭhiti. ‘‘Santi, bhikkhave, sattā sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma ‘natthi kiñcī’ti ākiñcaññāyatanūpagā. Ayaṃ sattamā viññāṇaṭṭhiti. Imā kho, bhikkhave, satta viññāṇaṭṭhitiyo’’ti. Paṭhamaṃ.
sections.english:
Monks, there are these seven stations of consciousness. Which seven?

Monks, there are beings with diverse bodies and diverse perceptions, such as humans, some devas, and some in states of woe. This is the first station of consciousness.

Monks, there are beings with diverse bodies but unified perception, such as the devas of the Brahma assembly who are reborn for the first time. This is the second station of consciousness.

Monks, there are beings with unified bodies but diverse perceptions, such as the Abhassara devas. This is the third station of consciousness.

Monks, there are beings with unified bodies and unified perception, such as the Subhakiṇha devas. This is the fourth station of consciousness.

Monks, there are beings who, by completely transcending perceptions of form, by the disappearance of perceptions of sensory impingement, and by not attending to perceptions of diversity, enter the realm of the infinitude of space, perceiving 'Space is infinite.' This is the fifth station of consciousness.

Monks, there are beings who, by completely transcending the base of the infinitude of space, enter the realm of the infinitude of consciousness, perceiving 'Consciousness is infinite.' This is the sixth station of consciousness.

Monks, there are beings who, by completely transcending the base of the infinitude of consciousness, enter the realm of nothingness, perceiving 'There is nothing at all.' This is the seventh station of consciousness.

These, monks, are the seven stations of consciousness.
sections.sinhala:
මහණෙනි, මේ විඤ්ඤාණස්ථාන සතකි. ඒ කවර සතක් ද යත්:

මහණෙනි, කාය වශයෙන් නානාවිධ වූ, සංඥා වශයෙන් නානාවිධ වූ සත්ත්වයෝ ඇත. ඒ කෙසේද යත්: මනුෂ්‍යයෝ ද, ඇතැම් දෙවියෝ ද, ඇතැම් විනිපාතික සත්වයෝ ද වෙති. මේ පළමු විඤ්ඤාණස්ථානය යි.

මහණෙනි, කාය වශයෙන් නානාවිධ වූ, සංඥා වශයෙන් ඒකවිධ වූ සත්ත්වයෝ ඇත. ඒ කෙසේද යත්: පළමුවෙන්ම උපන් බ්‍රහ්මකායික දෙවියෝ ය. මේ දෙවෙනි විඤ්ඤාණස්ථානය යි.

මහණෙනි, කාය වශයෙන් ඒකවිධ වූ, සංඥා වශයෙන් නානාවිධ වූ සත්ත්වයෝ ඇත. ඒ කෙසේද යත්: ආභස්සර දෙවියෝ ය. මේ තුන්වෙනි විඤ්ඤාණස්ථානය යි.

මහණෙනි, කාය වශයෙන් ඒකවිධ වූ, සංඥා වශයෙන් ඒකවිධ වූ සත්ත්වයෝ ඇත. ඒ කෙසේද යත්: සුභකිණ්හ දෙවියෝ ය. මේ සතරවෙනි විඤ්ඤාණස්ථානය යි.

මහණෙනි, යම් සත්ත්වයෝ සියලු රූපසංඥාවන් සම්පූර්ණයෙන් ඉක්මවා, පටිඝ සංඥාවන්ගේ අතුරුදහන් වීමෙන්, නානත්ව සංඥාවන් මෙනෙහි නොකිරීමෙන්, ‘අනන්තයි ආකාශය’යි කියා ආකාශානන්ත්‍යायतනයට පැමිණ සිටිත් ද, ඒ සත්ත්වයෝ ඇත. මේ පස්වෙනි විඤ්ඤාණස්ථානය යි.

මහණෙනි, යම් සත්ත්වයෝ සියලු ආකාශානන්ත්‍යायतනය සම්පූර්ණයෙන් ඉක්මවා, ‘අනන්තයි විඤ්ඤාණය’යි කියා විඤ්ඤාණානන්ත්‍යायतනයට පැමිණ සිටිත් ද, ඒ සත්ත්වයෝ ඇත. මේ සයවෙනි විඤ්ඤාණස්ථානය යි.

මහණෙනි, යම් සත්ත්වයෝ සියලු විඤ්ඤාණානන්ත්‍යायतනය සම්පූර්ණයෙන් ඉක්මවා, ‘කිසිවක් නැතැ’යි කියා ආකිංචඤ්ඤායතනයට පැමිණ සිටිත් ද, ඒ සත්ත්වයෝ ඇත. මේ සත්වෙනි විඤ්ඤාණස්ථානය යි.

මහණෙනි, මේ සත් විඤ්ඤාණස්ථාන යෝ යි.
sections.englishTitle: The Discourse on the Seven Stations of Consciousness

sections.pali: ‘‘Sattime, bhikkhave, samādhiparikkhārā. Katame satta? Sammādiṭṭhi, sammāsaṅkappo, sammāvācā, sammākammanto, sammāājīvo, sammāvāyāmo, sammāsati. Yā kho, bhikkhave, imehi sattahaṅgehi cittassekaggatā parikkhatā [‘saparikkhāratā’tipi, ‘saparikkhatā’tipi (saṃ. ni. 5.28)], ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, ariyo sammāsamādhi [samādhi (syā.)] saupaniso itipi saparikkhāro itipī’’ti. Dutiyaṃ.
sections.english: Monks, there are these seven requisites for concentration. Which seven? Right View, Right Intention, Right Speech, Right Action, Right Livelihood, Right Effort, and Right Mindfulness. Monks, the one-pointedness of mind that is equipped and supported by these seven factors is called Noble Right Concentration, for it has its underlying conditions and also its full set of requisites.
sections.sinhala:
භික්‍ෂූනි, සමාධියේ පරිවාර ධර්ම සතක් ඇත. ඒ කවර සතක්ද?
එනම්, නිවැරදි දැක්ම, නිවැරදි අරමුණ, නිවැරදි වචනය, නිවැරදි ක්‍රියාව, නිවැරදි දිවිපෙවෙත, නිවැරදි වෑයම, නිවැරදි සිහිය යන ධර්ම සතයි.
භික්‍ෂූනි, යම් සිතේ ඒකාග්‍රතාවයක් මේ අංග සතින් පිරිවරණ ලද්දේ වේද, භික්‍ෂූනි, මෙය උපනිශ්‍රය සහිත ආර්ය සම්මාසමාධිය යැයි ද, පරිවාර ධර්ම සහිත ආර්ය සම්මාසමාධිය යැයි ද කියනු ලැබේ.
sections.englishTitle: The Discourse on the Requisites of Concentration

sections.pali: ‘‘Sattime, bhikkhave, aggī. Katame satta? Rāgaggi, dosaggi, mohaggi, āhuneyyaggi, gahapataggi, dakkhiṇeyyaggi, kaṭṭhaggi – ime kho, bhikkhave, satta aggī’’ti. Tatiyaṃ.
sections.english: Monks, these are seven fires. Which seven? The fire of lust, the fire of hatred, the fire of delusion, the fire worthy of offerings, the householder’s fire, the fire worthy of donations, and the wood fire. These, monks, are the seven fires.
sections.sinhala: මහණෙනි, මේ ගිනි සතෙකි. ඒ කවර සතෙක්ද? රාග ගින්න, ද්වේෂ ගින්න, මෝහ ගින්න, ආහුණෙය්‍ය ගින්න, ගහපති ගින්න, දක්ඛිණෙය්‍ය ගින්න, දැව ගින්න – මහණෙනි, මේ ගිනි සත වේ.

sections.pali: Tena kho pana samayena uggatasarīrassa brāhmaṇassa mahāyañño upakkhaṭo hoti. Pañca usabhasatāni thūṇūpanītāni honti yaññatthāya, pañca vacchatarasatāni thūṇūpanītāni honti yaññatthāya, pañca vacchatarisatāni thūṇūpanītāni honti yaññatthāya, pañca ajasatāni thūṇūpanītāni honti yaññatthāya, pañca urabbhasatāni thūṇūpanītāni honti yaññatthāya. Atha kho uggatasarīro brāhmaṇo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi. Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho uggatasarīro brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘Sutaṃ metaṃ, bho gotama, aggissa ādānaṃ [ādhānaṃ (sī. syā.)] yūpassa ussāpanaṃ mahapphalaṃ hoti mahānisaṃsa’’nti. ‘‘Mayāpi kho etaṃ, brāhmaṇa, sutaṃ aggissa ādānaṃ yūpassa ussāpanaṃ mahapphalaṃ hoti mahānisaṃsa’’nti. Dutiyampi kho uggatasarīro brāhmaṇo…pe… tatiyampi kho uggatasarīro brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘sutaṃ metaṃ, bho gotama, aggissa ādānaṃ yūpassa ussāpanaṃ mahapphalaṃ hoti mahānisaṃsa’’nti. ‘‘Mayāpi kho etaṃ, brāhmaṇa, sutaṃ aggissa ādānaṃ yūpassa ussāpanaṃ mahapphalaṃ hoti mahānisaṃsa’’nti. ‘‘Tayidaṃ, bho gotama, sameti bhoto ceva gotamassa amhākañca, yadidaṃ sabbena sabbaṃ’’. Evaṃ vutte āyasmā ānando uggatasarīraṃ brāhmaṇaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘na kho, brāhmaṇa, tathāgatā evaṃ pucchitabbā – ‘sutaṃ metaṃ, bho gotama, aggissa ādānaṃ yūpassa ussāpanaṃ mahapphalaṃ hoti mahānisaṃsa’nti. Evaṃ kho, brāhmaṇa, tathāgatā pucchitabbā – ‘ahañhi, bhante, aggiṃ [aggissa (ka.)] ādātukāmo, [ādhātukāmo (sī. syā.)] yūpaṃ ussāpetukāmo. Ovadatu maṃ, bhante, bhagavā. Anusāsatu maṃ, bhante, bhagavā yaṃ mama assa dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyā’’’ti. Atha kho uggatasarīro brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘ahañhi, bho gotama, aggiṃ ādātukāmo yūpaṃ ussāpetukāmo. Ovadatu maṃ bhavaṃ gotamo. Anusāsatu maṃ bhavaṃ gotamo yaṃ mama assa dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyā’’ti. ‘‘Aggiṃ, brāhmaṇa, ādento [ādhento (sī. syā.)] yūpaṃ ussāpento pubbeva yaññā tīṇi satthāni ussāpeti akusalāni dukkhudrayāni [dukkhuddayāni (sī.)] dukkhavipākāni. Katamāni tīṇi? Kāyasatthaṃ, vacīsatthaṃ, manosatthaṃ. Aggiṃ, brāhmaṇa, ādento yūpaṃ ussāpento pubbeva yaññā evaṃ cittaṃ uppādesi – ‘ettakā usabhā haññantu yaññatthāya, ettakā vacchatarā haññantu yaññatthāya, ettakā vacchatariyo haññantu yaññatthāya, ettakā ajā haññantu yaññatthāya, ettakā urabbhā haññantu yaññatthāyā’ti. So ‘puññaṃ karomī’ti apuññaṃ karoti, ‘kusalaṃ karomī’ti akusalaṃ karoti, ‘sugatiyā maggaṃ pariyesāmī’ti duggatiyā maggaṃ pariyesati. Aggiṃ, brāhmaṇa, ādento yūpaṃ ussāpento pubbeva yaññā idaṃ paṭhamaṃ manosatthaṃ ussāpeti akusalaṃ dukkhudrayaṃ dukkhavipākaṃ. ‘‘Puna caparaṃ, brāhmaṇa, aggiṃ ādento yūpaṃ ussāpento pubbeva yaññā evaṃ vācaṃ bhāsati – ‘ettakā usabhā haññantu yaññatthāya, ettakā vacchatarā haññantu yaññatthāya, ettakā vacchatariyo haññantu yaññatthāya, ettakā ajā haññantu yaññatthāya, ettakā urabbhā haññantu yaññatthāyā’ti. So ‘puññaṃ karomī’ti apuññaṃ karoti, ‘kusalaṃ karomī’ti akusalaṃ karoti, ‘sugatiyā maggaṃ pariyesāmī’ti duggatiyā maggaṃ pariyesati. Aggiṃ, brāhmaṇa, ādento yūpaṃ ussāpento pubbeva yaññā idaṃ dutiyaṃ vacīsatthaṃ ussāpeti akusalaṃ dukkhudrayaṃ dukkhavipākaṃ. ‘‘Puna caparaṃ, brāhmaṇa, aggiṃ ādento yūpaṃ ussāpento pubbeva yaññā sayaṃ paṭhamaṃ samārambhati [samārabbhati (sī. ka.), samārabhati (syā.)] usabhā hantuṃ [haññantu (sī. syā.)] yaññatthāya, sayaṃ paṭhamaṃ samārambhati vacchatarā hantuṃ yaññatthāya, sayaṃ paṭhamaṃ samārambhati vacchatariyo hantuṃ yaññatthāya, sayaṃ paṭhamaṃ samārambhati ajā hantuṃ yaññatthāya, sayaṃ paṭhamaṃ samārambhati urabbhā hantuṃ yaññatthāya [haññantu yaññatthāyāti (sī. syā.)]. So ‘puññaṃ karomī’ti apuññaṃ karoti, ‘kusalaṃ karomī’ti akusalaṃ karoti, ‘sugatiyā maggaṃ pariyesāmī’ti duggatiyā maggaṃ pariyesati. Aggiṃ, brāhmaṇa, ādento yūpaṃ ussāpento pubbeva yaññā idaṃ tatiyaṃ kāyasatthaṃ ussāpeti akusalaṃ dukkhudrayaṃ dukkhavipākaṃ. Aggiṃ, brāhmaṇa, ādento yūpaṃ ussāpento pubbeva yaññā imāni tīṇi satthāni ussāpeti akusalāni dukkhudrayāni dukkhavipākāni. ‘‘Tayome, brāhmaṇa, aggī pahātabbā parivajjetabbā, na sevitabbā. Katame tayo? Rāgaggi, dosaggi, mohaggi. ‘‘Kasmā cāyaṃ, brāhmaṇa, rāgaggi pahātabbo parivajjetabbo, na sevitabbo? Ratto kho, brāhmaṇa, rāgena abhibhūto pariyādinnacitto kāyena duccaritaṃ carati, vācāya duccaritaṃ carati, manasā duccaritaṃ carati. So kāyena duccaritaṃ caritvā, vācāya duccaritaṃ caritvā, manasā duccaritaṃ caritvā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjati. Tasmāyaṃ rāgaggi pahātabbo parivajjetabbo, na sevitabbo. ‘‘Kasmā cāyaṃ, brāhmaṇa, dosaggi pahātabbo parivajjetabbo, na sevitabbo? Duṭṭho kho, brāhmaṇa, dosena abhibhūto pariyādinnacitto kāyena duccaritaṃ carati, vācāya duccaritaṃ carati, manasā duccaritaṃ carati. So kāyena duccaritaṃ caritvā, vācāya duccaritaṃ caritvā, manasā duccaritaṃ caritvā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjati. Tasmāyaṃ dosaggi pahātabbo parivajjetabbo, na sevitabbo. ‘‘Kasmā cāyaṃ, brāhmaṇa, mohaggi pahātabbo parivajjetabbo, na sevitabbo? Mūḷho kho, brāhmaṇa, mohena abhibhūto pariyādinnacitto kāyena duccaritaṃ carati, vācāya duccaritaṃ carati, manasā duccaritaṃ carati. So kāyena duccaritaṃ caritvā, vācāya duccaritaṃ caritvā, manasā duccaritaṃ caritvā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjati. Tasmāyaṃ mohaggi pahātabbo parivajjetabbo, na sevitabbo. Ime kho tayo, brāhmaṇa, aggī pahātabbā parivajjetabbā, na sevitabbā. ‘‘Tayo kho, brāhmaṇa, aggī sakkatvā garuṃ katvā mānetvā pūjetvā sammā sukhaṃ parihātabbā. Katame tayo? Āhuneyyaggi, gahapataggi, dakkhiṇeyyaggi. ‘‘Katamo ca, brāhmaṇa, āhuneyyaggi? Idha, brāhmaṇa, yassa te honti mātāti vā pitāti vā, ayaṃ vuccati, brāhmaṇa, āhuneyyaggi. Taṃ kissa hetu? Atohayaṃ [itopāyaṃ (ka.)], brāhmaṇa, āhuto sambhūto, tasmāyaṃ āhuneyyaggi sakkatvā garuṃ katvā mānetvā pūjetvā sammā sukhaṃ parihātabbo. ‘‘Katamo ca, brāhmaṇa, gahapataggi? Idha, brāhmaṇa, yassa te honti puttāti vā dārāti vā dāsāti vā pessāti vā kammakarāti vā, ayaṃ vuccati, brāhmaṇa, gahapataggi. Tasmāyaṃ gahapataggi sakkatvā garuṃ katvā mānetvā pūjetvā sammā sukhaṃ parihātabbo. ‘‘Katamo ca, brāhmaṇa, dakkhiṇeyyaggi? Idha, brāhmaṇa, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā parappavādā paṭiviratā khantisoracce niviṭṭhā ekamattānaṃ damenti, ekamattānaṃ samenti, ekamattānaṃ parinibbāpenti, ayaṃ vuccati, brāhmaṇa, dakkhiṇeyyaggi. Tasmāyaṃ dakkhiṇeyyaggi sakkatvā garuṃ katvā mānetvā pūjetvā sammā sukhaṃ parihātabbo. Ime kho, brāhmaṇa, tayo aggī sakkatvā garuṃ katvā mānetvā pūjetvā sammā sukhaṃ parihātabbā. ‘‘Ayaṃ kho pana, brāhmaṇa, kaṭṭhaggi kālena kālaṃ ujjaletabbo, kālena kālaṃ ajjhupekkhitabbo, kālena kālaṃ nibbāpetabbo, kālena kālaṃ nikkhipitabbo’’ti. Evaṃ vutte uggatasarīro brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘abhikkantaṃ, bho gotama; abhikkantaṃ, bho gotama…pe… upāsakaṃ maṃ bhavaṃ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gatanti. Esāhaṃ, bho gotama, pañca usabhasatāni muñcāmi jīvitaṃ demi, pañca vacchatarasatāni muñcāmi jīvitaṃ demi, pañca vacchatarisatāni muñcāmi jīvitaṃ demi, pañca ajasatāni muñcāmi jīvitaṃ demi, pañca urabbhasatāni muñcāmi jīvitaṃ demi. Haritāni ceva tiṇāni khādantu, sītāni ca pānīyāni pivantu, sīto ca nesaṃ vāto upavāyata’’nti [upavāyatūti (ka.)]. Catutthaṃ.

Now at that time, a great sacrifice had been prepared for the brahmin Uggatasarīra. Five hundred bulls were led to the posts for the sacrifice, five hundred steers were led to the posts for the sacrifice, five hundred heifers were led to the posts for the sacrifice, five hundred goats were led to the posts for the sacrifice, and five hundred rams were led to the posts for the sacrifice. Then the brahmin Uggatasarīra approached the Blessed One. Having approached, he exchanged greetings with the Blessed One. After exchanging polite and cordial talk, he sat down to one side. As he sat to one side, the brahmin Uggatasarīra said to the Blessed One, "I have heard this, Venerable Gotama, that setting up a fire and raising a sacrificial post yields great fruit and great benefit." "I too, brahmin, have heard this, that setting up a fire and raising a sacrificial post yields great fruit and great benefit," said the Blessed One. A second time, the brahmin Uggatasarīra... A third time, the brahmin Uggatasarīra said to the Blessed One, "I have heard this, Venerable Gotama, that setting up a fire and raising a sacrificial post yields great fruit and great benefit." "I too, brahmin, have heard this, that setting up a fire and raising a sacrificial post yields great fruit and great benefit," said the Blessed One. "Therefore, Venerable Gotama, this statement agrees with both yours and ours, in every respect." When this was said, Venerable Ānanda said to the brahmin Uggatasarīra, "Indeed, brahmin, Tathāgatas should not be questioned in this way: ‘I have heard this, Venerable Gotama, that setting up a fire and raising a sacrificial post yields great fruit and great benefit.’ Indeed, brahmin, Tathāgatas should be questioned in this way: ‘Venerable Sir, I desire to set up a fire and to raise a sacrificial post. May the Blessed One instruct me, Venerable Sir. May the Blessed One teach me what would be for my long-term welfare and happiness.’" Then the brahmin Uggatasarīra said to the Blessed One, "Indeed, Venerable Gotama, I desire to set up a fire and to raise a sacrificial post. May the Venerable Gotama instruct me. May the Venerable Gotama teach me what would be for my long-term welfare and happiness."

"Brahmin, when one sets up a fire and raises a sacrificial post, even before the sacrifice, one raises three weapons that are unwholesome, have a painful outcome, and a painful result. Which three? The weapon of body, the weapon of speech, and the weapon of mind. Brahmin, when one sets up a fire and raises a sacrificial post, even before the sacrifice, one generates such a thought in the mind: ‘Let so many bulls be slaughtered for the sacrifice, let so many steers be slaughtered for the sacrifice, let so many heifers be slaughtered for the sacrifice, let so many goats be slaughtered for the sacrifice, let so many rams be slaughtered for the sacrifice.’ Thinking ‘I am doing merit,’ one instead does demerit. Thinking ‘I am doing what is wholesome,’ one instead does what is unwholesome. Thinking ‘I am seeking the path to a good destination,’ one instead seeks the path to a bad destination. Brahmin, when one sets up a fire and raises a sacrificial post, even before the sacrifice, one thereby raises this first weapon of mind, which is unwholesome, has a painful outcome, and a painful result.

"Furthermore, brahmin, when one sets up a fire and raises a sacrificial post, even before the sacrifice, one utters such a speech: ‘Let so many bulls be slaughtered for the sacrifice, let so many steers be slaughtered for the sacrifice, let so many heifers be slaughtered for the sacrifice, let so many goats be slaughtered for the sacrifice, let so many rams be slaughtered for the sacrifice.’ Thinking ‘I am doing merit,’ one instead does demerit. Thinking ‘I am doing what is wholesome,’ one instead does what is unwholesome. Thinking ‘I am seeking the path to a good destination,’ one instead seeks the path to a bad destination. Brahmin, when one sets up a fire and raises a sacrificial post, even before the sacrifice, one thereby raises this second weapon of speech, which is unwholesome, has a painful outcome, and a painful result.

"Furthermore, brahmin, when one sets up a fire and raises a sacrificial post, even before the sacrifice, one oneself first undertakes to slaughter bulls for the sacrifice, oneself first undertakes to slaughter steers for the sacrifice, oneself first undertakes to slaughter heifers for the sacrifice, oneself first undertakes to slaughter goats for the sacrifice, oneself first undertakes to slaughter rams for the sacrifice. Thinking ‘I am doing merit,’ one instead does demerit. Thinking ‘I am doing what is wholesome,’ one instead does what is unwholesome. Thinking ‘I am seeking the path to a good destination,’ one instead seeks the path to a bad destination. Brahmin, when one sets up a fire and raises a sacrificial post, even before the sacrifice, one thereby raises this third weapon of body, which is unwholesome, has a painful outcome, and a painful result. Brahmin, when one sets up a fire and raises a sacrificial post, even before the sacrifice, one thereby raises these three weapons, which are unwholesome, have a painful outcome, and a painful result."

There are these three fires, brahmin, that should be abandoned, avoided, and not indulged. Which three? The fire of craving, the fire of aversion, and the fire of delusion.

And why, brahmin, should this fire of craving be abandoned, avoided, and not indulged? One who is stained by craving, brahmin, overcome and whose mind is consumed by it, commits misconduct by body, misconduct by speech, and misconduct by mind. Having committed misconduct by body, misconduct by speech, and misconduct by mind, with the breaking up of the body, after death, he reappears in a state of deprivation, a bad destination, a downfall, in hell. Therefore, this fire of craving should be abandoned, avoided, and not indulged.

And why, brahmin, should this fire of aversion be abandoned, avoided, and not indulged? One who is hostile, brahmin, overcome and whose mind is consumed by aversion, commits misconduct by body, misconduct by speech, and misconduct by mind. Having committed misconduct by body, misconduct by speech, and misconduct by mind, with the breaking up of the body, after death, he reappears in a state of deprivation, a bad destination, a downfall, in hell. Therefore, this fire of aversion should be abandoned, avoided, and not indulged.

And why, brahmin, should this fire of delusion be abandoned, avoided, and not indulged? One who is deluded, brahmin, overcome and whose mind is consumed by delusion, commits misconduct by body, misconduct by speech, and misconduct by mind. Having committed misconduct by body, misconduct by speech, and misconduct by mind, with the breaking up of the body, after death, he reappears in a state of deprivation, a bad destination, a downfall, in hell. Therefore, this fire of delusion should be abandoned, avoided, and not indulged. These are the three fires, brahmin, that should be abandoned, avoided, and not indulged.

There are these three fires, brahmin, that should be properly and happily attended to with respect, esteem, honor, and veneration. Which three? The fire worthy of offerings, the householder's fire, and the fire worthy of gifts.

And what, brahmin, is the fire worthy of offerings? Here, brahmin, whoever are your mother or your father, this is called, brahmin, the fire worthy of offerings. For what reason? From them, brahmin, you were offered and came into being. Therefore, this fire worthy of offerings should be properly and happily attended to with respect, esteem, honor, and veneration.

And what, brahmin, is the householder's fire? Here, brahmin, whoever are your children, or your wife, or your servants, or your employees, or your workers, this is called, brahmin, the householder's fire. Therefore, this householder's fire should be properly and happily attended to with respect, esteem, honor, and veneration.

And what, brahmin, is the fire worthy of gifts? Here, brahmin, those ascetics and brahmins who have withdrawn from other doctrines, who are established in patience and gentleness, who by themselves tame themselves, who by themselves bring themselves to peace, who by themselves attain complete liberation, this is called, brahmin, the fire worthy of gifts. Therefore, this fire worthy of gifts should be properly and happily attended to with respect, esteem, honor, and veneration. These are the three fires, brahmin, that should be properly and happily attended to with respect, esteem, honor, and veneration.

But as for this firewood fire, brahmin, it should be kindled from time to time, overseen from time to time, extinguished from time to time, and put away from time to time.

When this was said, the brahmin Uggatasarīra addressed the Blessed One thus: 'Excellent, good Gotama! Excellent, good Gotama! Just as if one were to set upright what had been overturned, or to reveal what was hidden, or to show the way to one who was lost, or to hold up a lamp in the darkness so that those with eyes could see forms—in the same way has the Blessed One expounded the Dhamma in various ways. I go for refuge to the Blessed One, and to the Dhamma, and to the Saṅgha. Let the Blessed One remember me as a lay follower who has taken refuge from this day forth as long as life lasts.' Then the brahmin said: 'Good Gotama, I release five hundred bulls, I give them life; I release five hundred male calves, I give them life; I release five hundred female calves, I give them life; I release five hundred goats, I give them life; I release five hundred rams, I give them life. Let them eat green grass, let them drink cool water, and let a cool breeze blow upon them.'

ඒ වේලෙහි, උග්ගතසරීර නම් බමුණාට මහා යාගයක් සූදානම් කර තිබුණි. යාගය සඳහා ගොනුන් පන්සීයක්, වස්සන් පන්සීයක්, වස්සීන් පන්සීයක්, එළුවන් පන්සීයක්, බැටළුවන් පන්සීයක් බැගින් කණු ළඟට ගෙනැවිත් තිබුණි.

ඉක්බිති උග්ගතසරීර බමුණා භාග්‍යවතුන් වහන්සේ වැඩසිටි තැනට පැමිණියේය. පැමිණ භාග්‍යවතුන් වහන්සේ සමඟ සමීපව කතා කළේය. සතුටු විය යුතු, සිහි කටයුතු කතාබහ නිමවා එකත්පස්ව වාඩි විය. එකත්පස්ව වාඩි වූ උග්ගතසරීර බමුණා භාග්‍යවතුන් වහන්සේට මෙසේ කීවේය: "භවත් ගෞතමයන් වහන්ස, ගින්න දැල්වීමත්, යූප කණුව එසවීමත් මහත් ඵල ඇති, මහත් ආනිශංස ඇති දෙයක් බව මම අසා ඇත්තෙමි." "බමුණ, ගින්න දැල්වීමත්, යූප කණුව එසවීමත් මහත් ඵල ඇති, මහත් ආනිශංස ඇති දෙයක් බව මමත් අසා ඇත්තෙමි." දෙවන වරටත් උග්ගතසරීර බමුණා භාග්‍යවතුන් වහන්සේට මෙසේ කීවේය: "භවත් ගෞතමයන් වහන්ස, ගින්න දැල්වීමත්, යූප කණුව එසවීමත් මහත් ඵල ඇති, මහත් ආනිශංස ඇති දෙයක් බව මම අසා ඇත්තෙමි." "බමුණ, ගින්න දැල්වීමත්, යූප කණුව එසවීමත් මහත් ඵල ඇති, මහත් ආනිශංස ඇති දෙයක් බව මමත් අසා ඇත්තෙමි." "භවත් ගෞතමයන් වහන්ස, මේ (අදහස) සම්පූර්ණයෙන්ම භවත් ගෞතමයන් වහන්සේගේ සහ අපගේ අදහස් සමග එකඟ වේ."

මෙසේ පැවසූ කල්හි ආයුෂ්මත් ආනන්ද ස්ථවිරයන් වහන්සේ උග්ගතසරීර බමුණාට මෙසේ වදාළ සේක: "බමුණ, 'භවත් ගෞතමයන් වහන්ස, ගින්න දැල්වීමත්, යූප කණුව එසවීමත් මහත් ඵල ඇති, මහත් ආනිශංස ඇති දෙයක් බව මම අසා ඇත්තෙමි' යනුවෙන් තථාගතයන් වහන්සේගෙන් ප්‍රශ්න නොකළ යුතුය. බමුණ, තථාගතයන් වහන්සේගෙන් මෙසේ ප්‍රශ්න කළ යුතුය: 'ස්වාමීනි, මම ගින්න දැල්වීමටත්, යූප කණුව එසවීමටත් කැමැත්තෙමි. ස්වාමීනි, භාග්‍යවතුන් වහන්සේ මට අවවාද කරන සේක්වා. ස්වාමීනි, භාග්‍යවතුන් වහන්සේ මට අනුශාසනා කරන සේක්වා, යමක් මට දීර්ඝ කාලයක් හිතසුව පිණිස වන්නේද' යනුවෙනි." ඉක්බිති උග්ගතසරීර බමුණා භාග්‍යවතුන් වහන්සේට මෙසේ කීවේය: "භවත් ගෞතමයන් වහන්ස, මම ගින්න දැල්වීමටත්, යූප කණුව එසවීමටත් කැමැත්තෙමි. භවත් ගෞතමයන් වහන්සේ මට අවවාද කරන සේක්වා. භවත් ගෞතමයන් වහන්සේ මට අනුශාසනා කරන සේක්වා, යමක් මට දීර්ඝ කාලයක් හිතසුව පිණිස වන්නේද."

"බමුණ, ගින්න දැල්වීමටත්, යූප කණුව එසවීමටත් කල්පනා කරන්නා යාගයටත් පෙර අකුසල, දුක් උපදවන, දුක් විපාක ඇති ශස්ත්‍ර තුනක් එසවූවා වේ. ඒ තුන කවරේද? කාය ශස්ත්‍රය, වචී ශස්ත්‍රය, මනෝ ශස්ත්‍රය. බමුණ, ගින්න දැල්වීමටත්, යූප කණුව එසවීමටත් කල්පනා කරන්නා යාගයටත් පෙර මෙවැනි සිතක් උපදවයි: ‘මේ තරම් ගොනුන් යාගය සඳහා මරනු ලැබේවා, මේ තරම් වස්සන් යාගය සඳහා මරනු ලැබේවා, මේ තරම් වස්සීන් යාගය සඳහා මරනු ලැබේවා, මේ තරම් එළුවන් යාගය සඳහා මරනු ලැබේවා, මේ තරම් බැටළුවන් යාගය සඳහා මරනු ලැබේවා’ කියාය. ඔහු ‘පිනක් කරමි’ කියා පවක් කරයි. ‘කුසලයක් කරමි’ කියා අකුසලයක් කරයි. ‘සුගතියට මඟ සොයමි’ කියා දුගතියට මඟ සොයයි. බමුණ, ගින්න දැල්වීමටත්, යූප කණුව එසවීමටත් කල්පනා කරන්නා යාගයටත් පෙර දුක් උපදවන, දුක් විපාක ඇති මේ පළමු මනෝ ශස්ත්‍රය එසවූවා වේ."

"තවද, බමුණ, ගින්න දැල්වීමටත්, යූප කණුව එසවීමටත් කල්පනා කරන්නා යාගයටත් පෙර මෙවැනි වචනයක් ප්‍රකාශ කරයි: ‘මේ තරම් ගොනුන් යාගය සඳහා මරනු ලැබේවා, මේ තරම් වස්සන් යාගය සඳහා මරනු ලැබේවා, මේ තරම් වස්සීන් යාගය සඳහා මරනු ලැබේවා, මේ තරම් එළුවන් යාගය සඳහා මරනු ලැබේවා, මේ තරම් බැටළුවන් යාගය සඳහා මරනු ලැබේවා’ කියාය. ඔහු ‘පිනක් කරමි’ කියා පවක් කරයි. ‘කුසලයක් කරමි’ කියා අකුසලයක් කරයි. ‘සුගතියට මඟ සොයමි’ කියා දුගතියට මඟ සොයයි. බමුණ, ගින්න දැල්වීමටත්, යූප කණුව එසවීමටත් කල්පනා කරන්නා යාගයටත් පෙර දුක් උපදවන, දුක් විපාක ඇති මේ දෙවන වචී ශස්ත්‍රය එසවූවා වේ."

"තවද, බමුණ, ගින්න දැල්වීමටත්, යූප කණුව එසවීමටත් කල්පනා කරන්නා යාගයටත් පෙර තෙමේම ප්‍රථමයෙන් ගොනුන් යාගය සඳහා මැරීමට පටන් ගනියි. තෙමේම ප්‍රථමයෙන් වස්සන් යාගය සඳහා මැරීමට පටන් ගනියි. තෙමේම ප්‍රථමයෙන් වස්සීන් යාගය සඳහා මැරීමට පටන් ගනියි. තෙමේම ප්‍රථමයෙන් එළුවන් යාගය සඳහා මැරීමට පටන් ගනියි. තෙමේම ප්‍රථමයෙන් බැටළුවන් යාගය සඳහා මැරීමට පටන් ගනියි. ඔහු ‘පිනක් කරමි’ කියා පවක් කරයි. ‘කුසලයක් කරමි’ කියා අකුසලයක් කරයි. ‘සුගතියට මඟ සොයමි’ කියා දුගතියට මඟ සොයයි. බමුණ, ගින්න දැල්වීමටත්, යූප කණුව එසවීමටත් කල්පනා කරන්නා යාගයටත් පෙර දුක් උපදවන, දුක් විපාක ඇති මේ තෙවන කාය ශස්ත්‍රය එසවූවා වේ. බමුණ, ගින්න දැල්වීමටත්, යූප කණුව එසවීමටත් කල්පනා කරන්නා යාගයටත් පෙර දුක් උපදවන, දුක් විපාක ඇති මේ ශස්ත්‍ර තුනම එසවූවා වේ."

බ්‍රාහ්මණය, මේ ගිනි තුනක් ඇත. ඒවා පහ කළ යුතු යි, දුරු කළ යුතු යි, සේවනය නොකළ යුතු යි. ඒ තුන කුමක් ද? රාගය නමැති ගින්න, ද්වේෂය නමැති ගින්න, මෝහය නමැති ගින්න යි.

බ්‍රාහ්මණය, මේ රාගය නමැති ගින්න පහ කළ යුත්තේ, දුරු කළ යුත්තේ, සේවනය නොකළ යුත්තේ කුමක් හෙයින් ද? බ්‍රාහ්මණය, රාගයෙන් ඇලුණේ, රාගයෙන් යටපත් වුණේ, සිත මුළා වුණේ, කයින් දුශ්චරිතයෙහි හැසිරෙයි, වචනයෙන් දුශ්චරිතයෙහි හැසිරෙයි, සිතින් දුශ්චරිතයෙහි හැසිරෙයි. හෙතෙම කයින් දුශ්චරිතයෙහි හැසිර, වචනයෙන් දුශ්චරිතයෙහි හැසිර, සිතින් දුශ්චරිතයෙහි හැසිර, කය බිඳී මරණින් මතු අපාය, දුර්ගති, විනිපාත නිරයෙහි උපදී. එහෙයින් මේ රාගය නමැති ගින්න පහ කළ යුතු යි, දුරු කළ යුතු යි, සේවනය නොකළ යුතු යි.

බ්‍රාහ්මණය, මේ ද්වේෂය නමැති ගින්න පහ කළ යුත්තේ, දුරු කළ යුත්තේ, සේවනය නොකළ යුත්තේ කුමක් හෙයින් ද? බ්‍රාහ්මණය, ද්වේෂයෙන් දූෂිත වුණේ, ද්වේෂයෙන් යටපත් වුණේ, සිත මුළා වුණේ, කයින් දුශ්චරිතයෙහි හැසිරෙයි, වචනයෙන් දුශ්චරිතයෙහි හැසිරෙයි, සිතින් දුශ්චරිතයෙහි හැසිරෙයි. හෙතෙම කයින් දුශ්චරිතයෙහි හැසිර, වචනයෙන් දුශ්චරිතයෙහි හැසිර, සිතින් දුශ්චරිතයෙහි හැසිර, කය බිඳී මරණින් මතු අපාය, දුර්ගති, විනිපාත නිරයෙහි උපදී. එහෙයින් මේ ද්වේෂය නමැති ගින්න පහ කළ යුතු යි, දුරු කළ යුතු යි, සේවනය නොකළ යුතු යි.

බ්‍රාහ්මණය, මේ මෝහය නමැති ගින්න පහ කළ යුත්තේ, දුරු කළ යුත්තේ, සේවනය නොකළ යුත්තේ කුමක් හෙයින් ද? බ්‍රාහ්මණය, මෝහයෙන් මුළා වුණේ, මෝහයෙන් යටපත් වුණේ, සිත මුළා වුණේ, කයින් දුශ්චරිතයෙහි හැසිරෙයි, වචනයෙන් දුශ්චරිතයෙහි හැසිරෙයි, සිතින් දුශ්චරිතයෙහි හැසිරෙයි. හෙතෙම කයින් දුශ්චරිතයෙහි හැසිර, වචනයෙන් දුශ්චරිතයෙහි හැසිර, සිතින් දුශ්චරිතයෙහි හැසිර, කය බිඳී මරණින් මතු අපාය, දුර්ගති, විනිපාත නිරයෙහි උපදී. එහෙයින් මේ මෝහය නමැති ගින්න පහ කළ යුතු යි, දුරු කළ යුතු යි, සේවනය නොකළ යුතු යි. බ්‍රාහ්මණය, මේ ගිනි තුන පහ කළ යුතු යි, දුරු කළ යුතු යි, සේවනය නොකළ යුතු යි.

බ්‍රාහ්මණය, ගිනි තුනක් ඇත. ඒවාට සත්කාර කොට, ගරු කොට, මැනවින් සලකා, පිදීමෙන් මනා කොට සැපසේ පවත්වාගෙන යා යුතු යි. ඒ තුන කුමක් ද? ආහුණෙය්‍ය අග්නිය, ගෘහපති අග්නිය, දක්ඛිණෙය්‍ය අග්නිය යි.

බ්‍රාහ්මණය, ආහුණෙය්‍ය අග්නිය යනු කුමක් ද? බ්‍රාහ්මණය, මෙහිලා යමෙකුට මව හෝ පියා වේ ද, බ්‍රාහ්මණය, මොවුන් ආහුණෙය්‍ය අග්නිය යැයි කියනු ලැබේ. එයට හේතුව කුමක් ද? මක්නිසාද යත්, බ්‍රාහ්මණය, (දරුවා) ඔවුන්ගෙන් උපත ලැබූ බැවින්, ඔවුහු පූජාවන්ට සුදුස්සෝ වෙති. එහෙයින් මේ ආහුණෙය්‍ය අග්නියට සත්කාර කොට, ගරු කොට, මැනවින් සලකා, පිදීමෙන් මනා කොට සැපසේ පවත්වාගෙන යා යුතු යි.

බ්‍රාහ්මණය, ගෘහපති අග්නිය යනු කුමක් ද? බ්‍රාහ්මණය, මෙහිලා යමෙකුට පුත්‍රයෝ හෝ භාර්යාවෝ හෝ දාසයෝ හෝ පේෂණකාරයෝ හෝ කම්කරුවෝ හෝ වෙත් ද, බ්‍රාහ්මණය, මොවුන් ගෘහපති අග්නිය යැයි කියනු ලැබේ. එහෙයින් මේ ගෘහපති අග්නියට සත්කාර කොට, ගරු කොට, මැනවින් සලකා, පිදීමෙන් මනා කොට සැපසේ පවත්වාගෙන යා යුතු යි.

බ්‍රාහ්මණය, දක්ඛිණෙය්‍ය අග්නිය යනු කුමක් ද? බ්‍රාහ්මණය, මෙහිලා යම් ශ්‍රමණයෝ හෝ බ්‍රාහ්මණයෝ හෝ වෙත් ද, පරවාදයෙන් (අන්‍ය මතයන්ගෙන්) වෙන්වූවාහු ද, ඉවසීමෙන් හා ශාන්තභාවයෙන් පිහිටියාහු ද, තමන්ම දමනය කරත් ද, තමන්ම සංසිඳුවත් ද, තමන්ම පිරිනිවන් පමුණුවත් ද, බ්‍රාහ්මණය, මොවුන් දක්ඛිණෙය්‍ය අග්නිය යැයි කියනු ලැබේ. එහෙයින් මේ දක්ඛිණෙය්‍ය අග්නියට සත්කාර කොට, ගරු කොට, මැනවින් සලකා, පිදීමෙන් මනා කොට සැපසේ පවත්වාගෙන යා යුතු යි. බ්‍රාහ්මණය, මේ ගිනි තුනට සත්කාර කොට, ගරු කොට, මැනවින් සලකා, පිදීමෙන් මනා කොට සැපසේ පවත්වාගෙන යා යුතු යි.

බ්‍රාහ්මණය, මේ දර ගින්න නම්, කලින් කලට දැල්විය යුතු යි, කලින් කලට නඩත්තු කළ යුතු යි, කලින් කලට නිවා දැමිය යුතු යි, කලින් කලට ඉවත දැමිය යුතු යි.

sections.english: Bhikkhus, these seven perceptions, when developed and frequently practiced, are greatly fruitful, greatly beneficial, having the Deathless as their culmination, with the Deathless as their ultimate aim. Which seven? The perception of repulsiveness, the perception of death, the perception of the loathsomeness of food, the perception of disenchantment with the entire world, the perception of impermanence, the perception of suffering in what is impermanent, and the perception of non-self in what is suffering. Indeed, bhikkhus, these seven perceptions, when developed and frequently practiced, are greatly fruitful, greatly beneficial, having the Deathless as their culmination, with the Deathless as their ultimate aim.

Sace pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno aniccasaññāparicitena cetasā bahulaṃ viharato lābhasakkārasiloke cittaṃ patilīyati patikuṭati pativattati, na sampasāriyati upekkhā vā pāṭikulyatā vā saṇṭhāti; veditabbametaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhunā ‘subhāvitā me aniccasaññā, atthi me pubbenāparaṃ viseso, pattaṃ me bhāvanābala’nti. Itiha tattha sampajāno hoti. ‘Aniccasaññā, bhikkhave, bhāvitā bahulīkatā mahapphalā hoti mahānisaṃsā amatogadhā amatapariyosānā’ti, iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ. ‘‘‘Anicce dukkhasaññā, bhikkhave, bhāvitā bahulīkatā mahapphalā hoti mahānisaṃsā amatogadhā amatapariyosānā’ti, iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ? Anicce dukkhasaññāparicitena, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno cetasā bahulaṃ viharato ālasye kosajje vissaṭṭhiye pamāde ananuyoge apaccavekkhaṇāya tibbā bhayasaññā paccupaṭṭhitā hoti, seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, ukkhittāsike vadhake. ‘‘Sace, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno anicce dukkhasaññāparicitena cetasā bahulaṃ viharato ālasye kosajje vissaṭṭhiye pamāde ananuyoge apaccavekkhaṇāya tibbā bhayasaññā, na paccupaṭṭhitā hoti, seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, ukkhittāsike vadhake. Veditabbametaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhunā ‘abhāvitā me anicce dukkhasaññā, natthi me pubbenāparaṃ viseso, appattaṃ me bhāvanābala’nti. Itiha tattha sampajāno hoti. Sace pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno anicce dukkhasaññāparicitena cetasā bahulaṃ viharato ālasye kosajje vissaṭṭhiye pamāde ananuyoge apaccavekkhaṇāya tibbā bhayasaññā paccupaṭṭhitā hoti, seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, ukkhittāsike vadhake. Veditabbametaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhunā ‘subhāvitā me anicce dukkhasaññā, atthi me pubbenāparaṃ viseso, pattaṃ me bhāvanābala’nti. Itiha tattha sampajāno hoti. ‘Anicce dukkhasaññā, bhikkhave, bhāvitā bahulīkatā mahapphalā hoti mahānisaṃsā amatogadhā amatapariyosānā’ti, iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ. ‘‘‘Dukkhe anattasaññā, bhikkhave, bhāvitā bahulīkatā mahapphalā hoti mahānisaṃsā amatogadhā amatapariyosānā’ti, iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ? Dukkhe anattasaññāparicitena, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno cetasā bahulaṃ viharato imasmiñca saviññāṇake kāye bahiddhā ca sabbanimittesu ahaṅkāramamaṅkāramānāpagataṃ mānasaṃ hoti vidhāsamatikkantaṃ santaṃ suvimuttaṃ. ‘‘Sace, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno dukkhe anattasaññāparicitena cetasā bahulaṃ viharato imasmiñca saviññāṇake kāye bahiddhā ca sabbanimittesu na ahaṅkāramamaṅkāramānāpagataṃ mānasaṃ hoti vidhāsamatikkantaṃ santaṃ suvimuttaṃ. Veditabbametaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhunā ‘abhāvitā me dukkhe anattasaññā, natthi me pubbenāparaṃ viseso, appattaṃ me bhāvanābala’nti. Itiha tattha sampajāno hoti. ‘‘Sace pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno dukkhe anattasaññāparicitena cetasā bahulaṃ viharato imasmiñca saviññāṇake kāye bahiddhā ca sabbanimittesu ahaṅkāramamaṅkāramānāpagataṃ mānasaṃ hoti vidhāsamatikkantaṃ santaṃ suvimuttaṃ. Veditabbametaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhunā ‘subhāvitā me dukkhe anattasaññā, atthi me pubbenāparaṃ viseso, pattaṃ me bhāvanābala’nti. Itiha tattha sampajāno hoti. ‘Dukkhe anattasaññā, bhikkhave, bhāvitā bahulīkatā mahapphalā hoti mahānisaṃsā amatogadhā amatapariyosānā’ti, iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ. ‘‘Imā kho, bhikkhave, satta saññā bhāvitā bahulīkatā mahapphalā honti mahānisaṃsā amatogadhā amatapariyosānā’’ti. Chaṭṭhaṃ.

Monks, there are these seven perceptions which, when developed and frequently practiced, are of great fruit and great benefit, having Nibbāna as their immersion and Nibbāna as their culmination. Which seven? The perception of foulness, the perception of death, the perception of repugnance in food, the perception of non-delight in the entire world, the perception of impermanence, the perception of suffering in what is impermanent, and the perception of non-self in what is suffering. These seven perceptions, monks, when developed and frequently practiced, are of great fruit and great benefit, having Nibbāna as their immersion and Nibbāna as their culmination.

‘The perception of foulness, monks, when developed and frequently practiced, is of great fruit and great benefit, having Nibbāna as its immersion and Nibbāna as its culmination.’ Indeed, this has been said. And in reference to what was it said? Monks, when a bhikkhu dwells frequently with a mind familiarized with the perception of foulness, his mind recoils from, shrinks away from, and turns back from sexual intercourse; it does not extend towards it, and indifference or repugnance remains established. Just as, monks, a chicken's feather or a strip of sinew, when thrown into a fire, recoils, shrinks away, and turns back, not extending itself. In the same way, monks, when a bhikkhu dwells frequently with a mind familiarized with the perception of foulness, his mind recoils from, shrinks away from, and turns back from sexual intercourse; it does not extend towards it, and indifference or repugnance remains established.

If, monks, when a bhikkhu dwells frequently with a mind familiarized with the perception of foulness, his mind inclines towards sexual intercourse and non-repugnance remains established; then that bhikkhu should know, ‘My perception of foulness is undeveloped; I have no distinction from before; I have not attained the power of development.’ Thus he becomes clearly comprehending in that regard. But if, monks, when a bhikkhu dwells frequently with a mind familiarized with the perception of foulness, his mind recoils from, shrinks away from, and turns back from sexual intercourse, it does not extend towards it, and indifference or repugnance remains established; then that bhikkhu should know, ‘My perception of foulness is well-developed; I have a distinction from before; I have attained the power of development.’ Thus he becomes clearly comprehending in that regard. That which was said: ‘The perception of foulness, monks, when developed and frequently practiced, is of great fruit and great benefit, having Nibbāna as its immersion and Nibbāna as its culmination,’ it was said in reference to this.

‘The perception of death, monks, when developed and frequently practiced, is of great fruit and great benefit, having Nibbāna as its immersion and Nibbāna as its culmination.’ Indeed, this has been said. And in reference to what was it said? Monks, when a bhikkhu dwells frequently with a mind familiarized with the perception of death, his mind recoils from, shrinks away from, and turns back from the craving for life; it does not extend towards it, and indifference or repugnance remains established. Just as, monks, a chicken's feather or a strip of sinew, when thrown into a fire, recoils, shrinks away, and turns back, not extending itself. In the same way, monks, when a bhikkhu dwells frequently with a mind familiarized with the perception of death, his mind recoils from, shrinks away from, and turns back from the craving for life; it does not extend towards it, and indifference or repugnance remains established.

If, monks, when a bhikkhu dwells frequently with a mind familiarized with the perception of death, his mind inclines towards the craving for life and non-repugnance remains established; then that bhikkhu should know, ‘My perception of death is undeveloped; I have no distinction from before; I have not attained the power of development.’ Thus he becomes clearly comprehending in that regard. But if, monks, when a bhikkhu dwells frequently with a mind familiarized with the perception of death, his mind recoils from, shrinks away from, and turns back from the craving for life, it does not extend towards it, and indifference or repugnance remains established; then that bhikkhu should know, ‘My perception of death is well-developed; I have a distinction from before; I have attained the power of development.’ Thus he becomes clearly comprehending in that regard. That which was said: ‘The perception of death, monks, when developed and frequently practiced, is of great fruit and great benefit, having Nibbāna as its immersion and Nibbāna as its culmination,’ it was said in reference to this.

‘The perception of repugnance in food, monks, when developed and frequently practiced, is of great fruit and great benefit, having Nibbāna as its immersion and Nibbāna as its culmination.’ Indeed, this has been said. And in reference to what was it said? Monks, when a bhikkhu dwells frequently with a mind familiarized with the perception of repugnance in food, his mind recoils from, shrinks away from, and turns back from the craving for tastes; it does not extend towards it, and indifference or repugnance remains established. Just as, monks, a chicken's feather or a strip of sinew, when thrown into a fire, recoils, shrinks away, and turns back, not extending itself. In the same way, monks, when a bhikkhu dwells frequently with a mind familiarized with the perception of repugnance in food, his mind recoils from, shrinks away from, and turns back from the craving for tastes; it does not extend towards it, and indifference or repugnance remains established.

Monks, if a monk, while dwelling much with a mind accustomed to the perception of repulsiveness in food, finds that his mind flows towards craving for flavors and non-repulsiveness becomes established, then, monks, he should understand this: 'My perception of repulsiveness in food is undeveloped; there is no difference in me between before and after; the power of my spiritual development has not been attained.' Thus, in that instance, he is clearly comprehending. But, monks, if a monk, while dwelling much with a mind accustomed to the perception of repulsiveness in food, finds that his mind recoils from craving for flavors, shrinks, shrivels, rolls back, and does not spread out, and either equanimity or repulsiveness becomes established, then, monks, he should understand this: 'My perception of repulsiveness in food is well-developed; there is a difference in me between before and after; the power of my spiritual development has been attained.' Thus, in that instance, he is clearly comprehending. Therefore, what was said—'The perception of repulsiveness in food, monks, when developed and repeatedly practiced, is of great fruit, of great benefit, culminates in the Deathless, and has the Deathless as its destination'—was said with reference to this.

Furthermore, what was said—'The perception of non-delight in the entire world, monks, when developed and repeatedly practiced, is of great fruit, of great benefit, culminates in the Deathless, and has the Deathless as its destination'—was said. What was this said with reference to? Monks, if a monk, while dwelling much with a mind accustomed to the perception of non-delight in the entire world, finds that his mind recoils from the fascinations of the world, shrinks, shrivels, rolls back, and does not spread out. Just as, monks, something recoils, shrivels, rolls back, and does not spread out. In the same way, monks, if a monk, while dwelling much with a mind accustomed to the perception of non-delight in the entire world, finds that his mind recoils from the fascinations of the world, shrinks, shrivels, rolls back, does not spread out, and either equanimity or repulsiveness becomes established.

Monks, if a monk, while dwelling much with a mind accustomed to the perception of non-delight in the entire world, finds that his mind flows towards the fascinations of the world and non-repulsiveness becomes established, then, monks, he should understand this: 'My perception of non-delight in the entire world is undeveloped; there is no difference in me between before and after; the power of my spiritual development has not been attained.' Thus, in that instance, he is clearly comprehending. But, monks, if a monk, while dwelling much with a mind accustomed to the perception of non-delight in the entire world, finds that his mind recoils from the fascinations of the world, shrinks, shrivels, rolls back, and does not spread out, and either equanimity or repulsiveness becomes established, then, monks, he should understand this: 'My perception of non-delight in the entire world is well-developed; there is a difference in me between before and after; the power of my spiritual development has been attained.' Thus, in that instance, he is clearly comprehending. Therefore, what was said—'The perception of non-delight in the entire world, monks, when developed and repeatedly practiced, is of great fruit, of great benefit, culminates in the Deathless, and has the Deathless as its destination'—was said with reference to this.

Furthermore, what was said—'The perception of impermanence, monks, when developed and repeatedly practiced, is of great fruit, of great benefit, culminates in the Deathless, and has the Deathless as its destination'—was said. What was this said with reference to? Monks, if a monk, while dwelling much with a mind accustomed to the perception of impermanence, finds that his mind recoils from gain, honor, and praise, shrinks, shrivels, rolls back, and does not spread out, and either equanimity or repulsiveness becomes established. Just as, monks, a chicken's feather or a piece of sinew thrown into a fire recoils, shrivels, rolls back, and does not spread out. In the same way, monks, if a monk, while dwelling much with a mind accustomed to the perception of impermanence, finds that his mind recoils from gain, honor, and praise, shrinks, shrivels, rolls back, and does not spread out, and either equanimity or repulsiveness becomes established.

Monks, if a monk, while dwelling much with a mind accustomed to the perception of impermanence, finds that his mind flows towards gain, honor, and praise and non-repulsiveness becomes established, then, monks, he should understand this: 'My perception of impermanence is undeveloped; there is no difference in me between before and after; the power of my spiritual development has not been attained.' Thus, in that instance, he is clearly comprehending. But, monks, if a monk, while dwelling much with a mind accustomed to the perception of impermanence, finds that his mind recoils from gain, honor, and praise, shrinks, shrivels, rolls back, and does not spread out, and either equanimity or repulsiveness becomes established, then, monks, he should understand this: 'My perception of impermanence is well-developed; there is a difference in me between before and after; the power of my spiritual development has been attained.' Thus, in that instance, he is clearly comprehending. Therefore, what was said—'The perception of impermanence, monks, when developed and repeatedly practiced, is of great fruit, of great benefit, culminates in the Deathless, and has the Deathless as its destination'—was said with reference to this.

Furthermore, what was said—'The perception of suffering in impermanence, monks, when developed and repeatedly practiced, is of great fruit, of great benefit, culminates in the Deathless, and has the Deathless as its destination'—was said. What was this said with reference to? Monks, if a monk, while dwelling much with a mind accustomed to the perception of suffering in impermanence, finds that a keen perception of danger is established concerning idleness, laziness, laxity, heedlessness, non-engagement in practice, and non-reflection, just as, monks, one would perceive danger from an assassin with a raised sword.

If, monks, for a bhikkhu dwelling frequently with a mind familiarized with the perception of suffering in impermanence, a strong perception of danger regarding idleness, laziness, slackness, heedlessness, lack of application, and lack of reflection is not present, just as, monks, if one were faced with an assassin with a raised sword. This, monks, should be understood by that bhikkhu: 'My perception of suffering in impermanence is undeveloped, there is no special progress for me compared to before, the power of development has not been attained by me.' Thus, he is clearly comprehending in that regard.

But if, monks, for a bhikkhu dwelling frequently with a mind familiarized with the perception of suffering in impermanence, a strong perception of danger regarding idleness, laziness, slackness, heedlessness, lack of application, and lack of reflection is present, just as, monks, if one were faced with an assassin with a raised sword. This, monks, should be understood by that bhikkhu: 'My perception of suffering in impermanence is well-developed, there is special progress for me compared to before, the power of development has been attained by me.' Thus, he is clearly comprehending in that regard. 'The perception of suffering in impermanence, monks, when developed and frequently practiced, is of great fruit and great benefit, culminating in the Deathless, ending in the Deathless,' it was said. It was with reference to this that it was said.

'The perception of non-self in suffering, monks, when developed and frequently practiced, is of great fruit and great benefit, culminating in the Deathless, ending in the Deathless,' it was said. With reference to what was this said? For a bhikkhu dwelling frequently with a mind familiarized with the perception of non-self in suffering, in this conscious body and in all external signs (phenomena), the mind becomes free from 'I-making,' 'mine-making,' and conceit, transcending all modes of measuring, peaceful, and well-liberated.

If, monks, for a bhikkhu dwelling frequently with a mind familiarized with the perception of non-self in suffering, in this conscious body and in all external signs (phenomena), the mind does not become free from 'I-making,' 'mine-making,' and conceit, transcending all modes of measuring, peaceful, and well-liberated. This, monks, should be understood by that bhikkhu: 'My perception of non-self in suffering is undeveloped, there is no special progress for me compared to before, the power of development has not been attained by me.' Thus, he is clearly comprehending in that regard.

But if, monks, for a bhikkhu dwelling frequently with a mind familiarized with the perception of non-self in suffering, in this conscious body and in all external signs (phenomena), the mind does become free from 'I-making,' 'mine-making,' and conceit, transcending all modes of measuring, peaceful, and well-liberated. This, monks, should be understood by that bhikkhu: 'My perception of non-self in suffering is well-developed, there is special progress for me compared to before, the power of development has been attained by me.' Thus, he is clearly comprehending in that regard. 'The perception of non-self in suffering, monks, when developed and frequently practiced, is of great fruit and great benefit, culminating in the Deathless, ending in the Deathless,' it was said. It was with reference to this that it was said.

'Indeed, monks, these seven perceptions, when developed and frequently practiced, are of great fruit and great benefit, culminating in the Deathless, ending in the Deathless.'
